technical_concept: A branch is not a copy of your code. It is a tiny file containing a single 40-character hash pointing to a commit. Creating a branch is instant because Git copies nothing — it just writes a new pointer. HEAD is another pointer that tells Git which branch you're currently on. Merging brings one branch's commits into another — always switch to the target branch first.

code_example.code:
HEAD
           │
         main
           │
           ▼
    C1 ◄── C2 ◄── C3          After: git switch -c feature
                    \
                     C4  ◄── feature  ◄── HEAD


    git branch                    # list all branches
    git switch -c feature         # create AND switch to new branch
    git switch main               # switch back
    git merge feature             # bring feature's commits into main
    git branch -d feature         # delete merged branch

challenge.task: Create a new branch called 'feature', switch to it, create a file 'feature.txt', stage and commit it with message 'Add feature', then switch back to main and merge the feature branch.
challenge.hint: Use 'git switch -c feature' to create and switch, then the usual add/commit cycle, then 'git switch main' and 'git merge feature'.
challenge.solution: git switch -c feature && echo 'new feature' > feature.txt && git add feature.txt && git commit -m 'Add feature' && git switch main && git merge feature

setup_commands: echo 'initial' > README.md && git add README.md && git commit -m 'Initial commit'

dialogue.line: Tell me — when you create a branch in your desktop tool, what do you believe happens?
Git makes a copy of all my files on the new branch, doesn't it?
A reasonable belief. And how long does it take?
It's instant. Even on large projects.
Instant! And yet you say Git copies all your files? Tell me — if I asked you to copy a thousand files, would that be instant?
No, that would take time. So... Git isn't copying files?
It is not. A branch is a tiny file — forty characters long — containing the hash of a commit. Nothing more. When you 'create a branch', Git writes one small file. That is why it is instant.
Just a pointer? Then what is HEAD?
Another pointer! HEAD points to the branch you are currently on. When you switch branches, only HEAD changes — it points to a different branch file. Study the diagram: pointers all the way down.
And merging?

When you merge, Git takes the commits from one branch and weaves them into another. But here is the crucial thing — you must first stand on the branch that will receive the work. Switch to main, then merge feature into it.
So I always go to the destination first, then merge the source into it?
Precisely. And after merging, the feature branch has served its purpose. Delete it. A clean workshop is a clear mind. Now — create a branch, do some work, come back, and merge. The full cycle.

styles.name: zen
styles.title: The Finger Pointing at the Moon

dialogue.line: What is a branch?
A copy of the code, so I can work without breaking things.
You describe what it does, not what it is. A branch is not a tree. It is a finger pointing at the moon.
I don't understand.
A branch is a pointer — forty characters written in a small file. It points to a commit, nothing more. Git copies nothing when you create a branch. It writes one line.
That's why it's instant?
You begin to see. And HEAD — do you know what HEAD is?
The current commit?
Close. HEAD is a pointer to a branch, which is a pointer to a commit. A finger pointing at a finger pointing at the moon. 'git switch' simply moves where HEAD points.
And merging brings two branches together?
Yes, but with intention. First stand where you want the river to flow — switch to the receiving branch. Then invite the other stream in. 'git merge' joins the streams.
What happens to the feature branch after?
It has done its work. Release it. 'git branch -d' removes the pointer. The commits remain — they are now part of main's history. Now go: create, branch, work, return, merge. Feel the cycle.
